title: Special Teams Explained
subtitle: The Hidden Third of Football - Kicks, Punts, and Returns

What you'll learn: The three phases of football (offense, defense, special teams)

script.hook: They say football is three games in one: offense, defense, and special teams. That third one? It decides more games than you'd think.

sections.title: The Third Phase
sections.content: Special teams handle all kicking plays: kickoffs to start drives, punts to flip field position, field goals to score, and extra points after touchdowns. These units feature specialists who only play these crucial moments.
sections.onScreen: three-way split: OFFENSE | DEFENSE | SPECIAL TEAMS with examples

sections.title: Kickoffs - Starting Fresh
sections.content: Games start with a kickoff from the 35-yard line. The kicker boots it deep, the receiving team catches and returns it. Where they're tackled determines field position. Great returns can swing momentum instantly.

sections.title: Punting - The Position Battle
sections.content: On 4th down, teams usually punt - kicking the ball away to make the opponent start farther back. The punter drops the ball and kicks it before it hits the ground. Good punts pin opponents deep; bad ones give them great field position.

sections.title: Field Goals - Three Point Attempts
sections.content: When teams can't score touchdowns but are close enough (usually within 50 yards), they attempt field goals. The kicker must send the ball through the uprights - those tall yellow posts. Distance and wind make this harder than it looks.
sections.onScreen: field goal attempt angles + success rates by distance chart

sections.title: Hidden Impact Players
sections.content: Special teams features unique positions: place kicker, punter, long snapper (snaps for kicks), holder (holds for field goals), returners (catch and run back kicks), and gunners (first ones downfield on punts). Each role is specialized.
sections.onScreen: special teams position grid with role descriptions

sections.title: Why It Matters
sections.content: Special teams accounts for 30% of plays but can determine 100% of outcomes. Blocked punts, missed field goals, and touchdown returns are game-changers. Never underestimate the kicking game!
sections.onScreen: 'SPECIAL TEAMS WINS GAMES' + famous game-winning kicks montage

quiz.question: It's 4th & 8 from the opponent's 35-yard line. Your team is up by 2 points with 3 minutes left. What's the best special teams decision?
quiz.explanation: Good call! A 52-yard field goal is makeable for football kickers. If successful, you go up by 5 points (requiring a touchdown to beat you). Missing still leaves them at their 35 - not much different from a punt.
quiz.encouragement: You understand special teams strategy! Field position and score determine these crucial decisions.

keyTerms.definition: A kick from the 35-yard line that starts each half and follows scoring plays
A kick where the ball is dropped and kicked before hitting the ground, used to change possession
A 3-point scoring attempt by kicking the ball through the uprights
When a kickoff or punt goes into the end zone and isn't returned, starting at the 25-yard line
A punt aimed at landing out of bounds near the opponent's goal line
